title: Q. B
body: B. D. An abbreviation of “Queen’s Bench Division.”

title: Q. C
body: F. An abbreviation of “quare clausum fregit,” (q. v

title: Q. E
body: N. An abbreviation of “quare exe-cutionem non," wherefore execution [should] not [be issued

title: Quack
body: A pretender to medical skill which he does not possess; one who practices as a physician or surgeon without adequate preparation or due qualification. See El-mergreen v. Horn, 115 wis. 385, 91 N. W. 973

title: Quacunque Vta Data
body: Lat. whichever way you take it

title: Quadragesima
body: Lat The fortieth. The first Sunday iu Lent is so called because it is about the fortieth day before Easter. Oowell

title: Quadragesimals
body: offerings former-ly made, on Mid-Lent Sunday, to the mother church

title: Quadragesms
body: The third volume of the year bodks of the reign of Edward III. So called because beginning with the fortieth year of that sovereign’s reign. Crabb, Eng. Law, 327

title: Quadrans
body: Lat. In Roman law. The fourth part; the quarter of any number, measure, or quantity. Hence an heir to the fourth part of the inheritance was called “baeres ex quadrante” Also a Roman coin, being the fourth part of an as, equal in value to an English half-penny

title: Quadrant
body: An angular measure of ninety degrees

title: Quadrantata Terrs
body: In old

title: Quadrarium
body: In old records. A stone-pit or quarry. Cowell

title: Quadrienntdm
body: Lat. In the civil law. The four-years course ot study re-qulred to be pursued by law-students before they were qualified to study the Code or collection of imperial constltutlotB. See Inst proem

title: Quadriennium Utile
body: In Scotch law. The term of four years allowed to a minor, after his majority, in which he may by suit or action endeavor to annul any deed to his prejudice, granted during his minority. Bell

title: Quadripartite
body: Divided into four parts. A term applied.in conveyancing to an indenture executed in four parts

title: Quadroon
body: A person who is descended from a white person and another person who has an §qual mixture of the European and African blood. State v. Davis, 2 Bailey (S. C.) 558

title: Quadruplatores
body: Lat in Romau law. Informers who, lf their information were followed by conviction, had the fourth part of the confiscated goods for their trouble

title: Quadruplicatio
body: Lat in the civU law. A pleading on the part of a defendant, corresponding to the rebutter at common law. The third pleading on the part of the defendant. Inst. 4, 14, 3; 3 BL Comm. 310

title: Quje Est Eadem
body: Lat which is the same, words used for alleging that the trespass or other fact mentioned in the plea is the same as that laid in the declaration, where, from the circumstances, there is au apparent difference between the two. 1 ChiL Pl. *582

title: Quje Nihil Frustra
body: Lat which [does or requires] nothing in vain, which requires nothing to be done, that is, to no purpose. 2 Kent, Comm. 53

title: Quje Plura
body: Lat in old Engllsh practice. A writ which lay where an inqnl-sltlon had been made by an escheator in any county of such lands or tenements as any man died seised of, and all that was in his possession was imagined not to be found by the office; the writ commanding the es-cheator to inquire what more (qua plura) lands and tenements the party held on the day when he died, etc. Fitzh. Net. Brev. 255a; Cowell

title: Quxre
body: A query; question; doubt This word, occurring in the syllabus of a re-ported case or elsewhere, shows that a ques-tion ia propounded as to what follows, or that the particular rule, decision, or state-ment is considered as open to question

title: Qujerens Non Invenit Plegium
body: L^ Lat. The plaintiff did not find a pledge. A return formerly made by a sheriff to a writ requiring him to take security of the plaintiff to prosecute hls- claim. Cowell.

title: Qujesta
body: An lndulgence or remlsslon of penance, sold by the pope

title: Quxstio
body: In Roman law. Anclently a specles of commissiou granted by the eomitia to one or more persons for the pur-pose of inquiring into some crime or public offense and reporting thereon. In later tlmes. the qu (ratio came to exerclse plenary criminal jurisdiction, even to pronouncing sentence, and then was appointed periodical-ly, and eventually became a permanent corn-mission or regular criminal tribunal, and was then called “queeatio perpetual See Maine, Anc. Law, 369-372

title: Quabstionarh
body: Those who carried queeata about from door to door

title: Qujbstor
body: Lat A Roman magistrate, -whose office it was to collect the public rev-enue. Varro de L. L. iv. 14

title: Qujestus
body: L. Lat. That estate wbich a man has by acquisition or purchase, in con-tradistinction to “hareditaa” which is what he has by descent Glan. 1, 7, c. 1

title: Quaker
body: This, in England, is the stat-ntory, as well as the popular, name of a member of a religious society, by themselves deupminated “Frleuds

title: Quale Jus
body: Lat. In old English law

title: Qualification
body: The possession by an lndlvldual of the qualities, properties, or

title: Qualify
body: To make one’s self fit or pre-pared to exercise a right, office, or franchise. To take the steps necessary to prepare one’s self for an office or appointment, as by tak-lng oath, glvlng bond, etc. Pub. St. Mass, p. 1294; Archer v. State, 74 Md. 443, 22 Atl. 8, 28 Am. St. Rep. 261; Hale v. Salter, 25 La. Ann. 324; State v. Albert, 55 Kan. 154, 40 Pac. 286

title: Quality
body: In respect to persons, this term denotes comparative rank; state or condition in relation to others; social or civil position or class. .In pleading, it means ap

title: Quamdiu
body: Lat As long as; so long as. A word of limitation in old conveyances. Co. Litt 235a

title: Quamdiu Sb Bene Gesserit
body: As

title: Quando Aociderint
body: .Lat when they shall come In. The name of a judgment sometimes given against an executor, especially on a plea of plene administrarif, wbich empowers the plaintiff to have the benefit of assets which may at any time thereafter come to the hands of the executor

title: Quanti Minoris
body: Lat. The name of an action in the civil law, (and in Louisiana,) brought by the purchaser of an article, for a reduction of the agreed price on account of defects in the thing which diminish its value

title: Quantum Meruit
body: As much as he deserved. In pleading.- The common count in an action of assumpsit for work and labor, founded on an implied assumpsit or promise on the part of the defendant to pay the plaintiff as much as he reasonably deserved to have for his labor. 3 BL Comm. 161; 1 Tidd, Pr. 2

title: Quantum Valebant
body: As much as they were worth. In pleadlng. The com-mon count In an action of assumpsit for goods sold and delivered, founded on an implled assumpsit or promise, on the part of the defendant, to pay the plaintiff as much as the goods were reasonably worth. 3 Bl

title: Quarantine
body: A period of time (theoretically forty days) during which a vessel, coming from a place where a contagious or Infectious disease is prevalent, is detained by authority in the harbor of her port of destl-nation, or at a station near it, without being permitted to land or to discharge her crew or passengers. Quarantine is said to have been first established at Venice in 1484. Baker, Quar. 3

title: Quare
body: Lat wherefore; for what rea-son; on what account. Used in the Latin - form of several common-law writs

title: Quare Clausum Fregit
body: Lat

title: Quare Ejecit Infra Terminum
body: wherefore he ejected within the term. In old practice. A writ which lay for a lessee where he was ejected before the expiration of hls term, in cases where the wrong-doer or ejector was not himself in possession of the lands, but his feoffee or another claiming under him. 3 Bl. Comm. 199, 206; Reg. orig. 227; Fltzh. Nat Brev. 197 S.

title: Quare Impedit
body: wherefore he hin-ders. In English practice. A writ or action which lies for* the patron of an advowson, where he has been disturbed in his right of patronage; so called from the emphatic words of the old form, by which the dlsturh-er was summoned to answer why he hinders the plaintifT. 3 Bl. Comm. 246, 248

title: Quare Incumbravit
body: In English law. A writ which lay against a bishop who, within six months after the vacation of a benefice, conferred it on his clerk, whlle two others were contendlng at law for the right of presentation, calling upon him to show cause why he had Incumbered the church. Reg. orlg. 32. Abollshed by 3 & 4 wm. IV. c. 27

title: Quare Intrusit
body: A writ that for-merly lay where the lord proffered a sultable marriage to hls ward, who rejected It, and entered into the land, and married another, the value of hls marriage not being satisfied to the lord. Abolished by 12 Car. II. c. 24

title: Quare Non Admibit
body: In Engllsh law. A writ to recover damages against a bishop who does not admit a plaintifTs clerk. It is, however, rarely or never necessary; for it is said that a bishop, refusing to execute the writ ad admittcndum clericum, or mak-lng an Insufficient return to it, may he fined, wats. Cler. Law, 302

title: Quare Obstruxit
body: wherefore he obstructed. In old English practice. A writ which lay for one who, having a liberty to pass through his neighbor’s ground, could

title: Quarentena Terra
body: A furlong. Co. Lltt 5b

title: Quarrel
body: This word is said to extend not only to real and personal actions, hut also to the causes of actions and suits; so that by the release of all “quarrels," not only actions pending, but also causes of action and suit, are released; and “quarrels,” “con-troversies,” and "debates” are in law con-sidered as having the same meaning. Co. Litt 8, 153; Termes de la Ley

title: Quarry
body: In mining law. An open excavation where the works* are visible at the surface; a place or pit where stone, slate, marble, etc., is dug out or separated from a mass of rock. Baiub. Mines, 2. See Marvel v. Merritt, 116 U. S. 11, 6 Sup. Ct. 207, 29 L. Ed. 550; Murray v. Allred, 100 Tenn. 100, 43 S. W. 355, 39 L. R. A. 249, 66 Am. St Rep. 740; Ruttledge v. Eress, 17 Pa. Super. Ct. 495

title: Quart
body: A llquid measure, containing* one-fourth part of a gallon

title: Quarta Falcidia
body: In Roman law. That portion of a testator’s estate whlch, by the Falcidian law, was required to be left to the heir, amounting to at least one-fourth. See Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 771

title: Quarter
body: The fourth part of any-thlng. especlally of a year. Also a length of four inches. In England, a measure of corn, generally reckoned at eight bushels, though subject to local variations. See Hospltal St. Cross v. Lord Howard De walden, 6 Term, 343. In Amerlcan land law, a quarter sec-tion of land. See infra. And see McCart-ney v. Dennison, 101 Cal. 252, 35 Pac 766

title: Quarter Sessions
body: In Enclisb law. A criminal court held before two or more justlces of the peace, (one of whom must be of the quorum,) in every county, once in every quarter of a year. 4 BL Comm. 271; 4 Steph. Comm. 335

title: Quartering
body: In English criminal law. The dlviding a criminal's body into quarters, after execution. A part of the punishment of high treason. 4 Bl. Comm. 93

title: Quartering Soldiers
body: Tbe act of

title: Quarterization
body: Quartering of crim-lnals

title: Quarterly Courts
body: A system of courts in Kentucky possessing a limited orig-lnal jurisdictlon in clvll cases and appellate jurisdlction from justices of the peace

title: Quarterone
body: In the Spanish and French west Indies, a quadroon, that is, a person one of whose parents was white and the other a mulatto. See Daniel v. Guy, 19 Ark. 131.

title: Quarto Die Fost
body: Lat on the

title: Quash
body: To overthrow; to abate; to an-nul; to make void. Spelman; 3 Bl. Comm. 303; Crawford v. Stewart, 38 Pa. 34; Hoi-land v. webster, 43 Fla,. 85^29 South. 625; Bosley v. Bruner, 2 Cushm. (Miss.) 462

title: Quasi
body: Let As lf; as it were; anal-ogous to. This term is used in legal phrase

title: Quater Cousin
body: See Cousin

title: Quatuor Pedibus Currit
body: Lat

title: Quatuorviri
body: In Roman law. Mag-tetrates who had the care and inspection of roads. Dig. 1, 2, 3, 30

title: Quay
body: A wharf for the loading or un-loading of goods carried in ships. This word is sometimes spelled “key

title: Que Est Le Mesme
body: L. Fr. whlch is the same. A term used in actions of trespass, etc. See Quje est Eadbx

title: Que Estate
body: L. Fr. whose estate. A term used in pleading, particularly in claiming prescrlptlon, by whlch it is alleged that the plalntlff and those former owners whose estate he has have lmmemorlally exer--clsed the right claimed. Thls was called “prescribing in a que estate.’’

title: Quean
body: A worthless woman; a strum-pet. obsolete

title: Queen
body: A woman who possesses the soverelgnty and royal power in a country under a monarchical form of government The wife of a klng

title: Queen Anne'S Bounty
body: A fund created by a charter of Queen Anne, (con-firmed by St 2 Ann. c. 11,) for the augmenta-tion of poor livings, consisting of all the revenue of first fruits and tenths, which was vested in trustees forever. 1 Bl. Comm. 286

title: Queen'S Prison
body: A Jail which used to be appropriated to the debtors and crimi-nals confined under process or by authority of the superior courts at westminster, the high court of admiralty, and also to per-sons imprisoned under the bankrupt law

title: Quem Reditum Reddit
body: L. Lat. An old writ which lay where a rent-charge or other rent which was not rent service was granted by fine holding of the grantor. If the tenant would not attorn, then the grantee might have had this writ old Nat. Brev. 126

title: Querela
body: Lat. An action preferred in any court of justice. The plaintiff was called “querens," or complainant and hls brief, complaint, or declaration was called “querela." Jacob

title: Querela Coram Rege A Con-Cilio Discutienda Et Termi-Nanda
body: A writ by which one is called to justify a complaint of a trespass made to the king himself, before the king and his council. Reg. orlg. 124

title: Querela Inofficiosi Testamenti
body: Lat. In the civil law. A species of action allowed to a child who had been unjustly disinherited, to set aside the will, founded on the presumption of law, in such

title: Querens
body: Lat. A plaintiff; complain-ant; Inquirer

title: Questa
body: In old records. A quest; an inquest, inquisition, or inquiry, upon the oaths of an Impaneled jury. Oowell

title: Question
body: A method of criminal ex-amination heretofore in use in some of the countries of continental Europe, consisting of the application of torture to the supposed criminal, by means of the rack or other engines, in order to- extort from him, as the condition of his release from the torture, a confession of his own guilt or the names of his accomplices

title: Questmonger
body: r QUESTMONGER. In

title: Questores Parricidii
body: Lat. In Roman law. Certain officers, two in number, who were deputed by the eomitia, as a kind of commission, to search out and try all cases of parricide and murder. They were proba-bly appointed annually. Maine, Anc. Law, 370

title: Questus Est Nobis
body: Lat A writ of nuisance, whicb, by 15 Fdw. I., lay against him to whom a house or other thing that caused a nuisance descended or was alienated ; whereas, before that statute the action lay only against him who first levied or caus-ed the nuisance to the damage of his neigh-bor. Cowell

title: Quia
body: Lat. Because; whereas; inasmuch as

title: Quia Datum Est Nobis Intelll
body: GI. Because it is given to us to understand. Formal words in old writs,

title: Quia Emftores
body: “Because the pur-chasere.” The title of the statute of westm. S. (18 Edw. L c. 1.) This statute took from the tenants of common lords the feudal lib-erty they claimed of disposing of part of their lands to hold of themselves, and, in-stead of it, gave them a general liberty to sell all or any part, to hold of the next superlor lord, which they could not have done before without consent The effect of this statute was twofold: (1) To facilitate the alienation of fee-simple estates; and (2) to put an end to the creation of any new manors, i. e., tenancies in fee-simple of a sub-ject Brown

title: Quia Erronice Emanavit
body: Because it issued erroneously, or through mis-take. A term in old English practice. Tel. 83

title: Quia Timet
body: Lat Because he fears or apprehends. In equity practice. The technical name of a blll filed by a party who seeks the ald of a court of equity, because he fears some future probable injury to his rights or interests. 2 Story, Eq. Jur. | 826

title: Quibble
body: A cavilling or verbal ohjec-tion. A sllght difllculty raised without ne-cesslty or propriety

title: Quick
body: Living; alive. “Quick chattels must be put in pound-overt that the owner may give them sustenance; dead need not" Finch, Law, b. 2, c. 6

title: Quick With Child
body: See QUICKEN-IN G

title: Quickening
body: ln medical jurispru-dence. The first motion of the foetus in the womb felt by the mother, occurring usually about the middle of the term of pregnancy. See Com. v. Parker, 9 Metc. (Mass.) 266, 43 Am. Dec. 396; State v. Cooper, 22 N. J. Law, 57, 51 Am. Dec. 248; Evans v. People, 49 N. Y. 89.

title: Quid Juris Clamat
body: In old Eng-llsh practice. A writ which lay for the grantee of a reversion or remainder, where the particular tenant would not attorn, for the purpose of compelling him. Termes de la Ley; Cowell

title: Quid Fro Quo
body: what for what; something for something. Used in law for the giving one valuable thing for another. It is nothing more than the mutual consideration which passes between the parties to a con-tract, and which renders it valid and binding. Cowell

title: Quidam
body: Lat. Somebody. This term is used in the French law to designate a person whose name is not known

title: Quietare
body: L. Lat. To quit, acquit, discharge, or save harmless. A formal word in old deeds of donation and other convey-ances. CowelL

title: Quiete Clamantia
body: L. Lat. In old English law. Quitclaim. Bract, fol. 33b

title: Quiete Clamare
body: L. Lat To quit-claim or renounce ali pretensions of right and title. Bract fols. 1, 5

title: Quietus
body: In old English law. Quit; acquitted; discharged. A word used by the clerk of the pipe, and auditors in the exchequer, in their acquittances or discharges given to accountants; usuaily concluding with an abinde recessit quietus, (hath gone quit thereof,) which was called a “quietus est" CowelL

title: Quelle
body: In French marine law. Keel; the keel of a vessel. Ord. Mar. liv. 3, tlt 6, art 8

title: Quinque Portus
body: In old English law. The Cinque Ports. Spelman

title: Quinquepartite
body: Consisting of five parts; divided lnto five parts

title: Quinzime
body: E, or QUINZIME. Fif-teenths; also the fifteenth day after a festi-val. 13 Edw. I. See Cowell

title: Quinterone
body: A term used in the West Indles to designate a person one of whose parents was a-whlte person and the other, a quadroon. Also spelled “quintroon.” See Daniel v. Guy, 19 Ark. 131

title: Quinto Exactus
body: In old practice. Called or exacted the fifth tlme. A return made by the sheriff, after a defendant had been proclaimed, required, or exacted in five county courts successively, and falled to appear, upon which he was outlawed by the coroners of the county. 3 BL Comm. 283

title: Quire Op Dover
body: In English law. A record in the exchequer, showing the ten-ures for guarding and repairing Dover Cas-tle, and determining the services of the Ctnque Ports. 3 How. State Tr. 868

title: Quiritarian Ownership
body: In Ro

title: Quitrent
body: Certain establlshed rents of the freeholders and ancient copyholders of manors are denominated “qultrents,” because thereby the tenant goes quit and free of all other services. 3 Cruise, Dig. 314

title: Quittance
body: An abbreviation of “ac

title: Quo Animo
body: Lat. with what Intention or motive. Used sometimes as a substantive, in lieu of the single word “animus,” design or motive. “The quo animo is the real subject of Inquiry.” 1 Kent, Comm. 77

title: Quo Jure
body: Lat. In old Engllsh prac* tice. A writ which lay for one that had land in which another claimed common, to compel the latter to show bg what title he claimed it CoweU; Fitzh. Nat. Brev. 128, F

title: Quo Minus
body: Lat. A writ upon which all proceedings in the court of exchequer were formerly grounded. In it the plaintiff suggests that he is the king’s debtor, and that the defendant has done him the Injury or damage complained of, quo minus sufflcienS existit, by which he is less able to pay the king’s debt This was originally requisite in order to give Jurisdiction to the court of ex-chequer; but now this suggestion is a mere form. 3 Bl. Comm. 46

title: Quoad Hoc
body: Lat. As to this; with respect to this; so far as this in particular is concerned

title: Quoad Sacra
body: Lat As to sacred things; for religious purposes

title: Quod Billa Cassetur
body: That the bill be quashed. The common-law form of a judgment sustaining a plea in abatement, where the proceeding is by bill, i. e., by a capias instead of by original writ

title: Quod Clerici Beneficiati De Cangellaria
body: A writ to exempt a clerk of the chahcery from the contribution to-wards the proctors of the clergy in parlia-ment, etc. Reg. orlg. 261

title: Quod Computet
body: That he account Judgment quod computet is a preliminary or interlocutory judgment given in the action of account-render (also in the case of cred-itors’ bllls against au executor or administrator,) directing that accouhts be taken be-fore a master or auditor

title: Quod Cum
body: In pleading. For that whereas. A form of introducing matter of inducement in certain actions, as assumpsit and case

title: Quod Fuit Concessum
body: which was granted. A phrase in the reports, signify-ing that an argument or poiut made was conceded or acquiesced in by the court

title: Quod Jussu
body: LaL In the civil law. The name of an action given to one who had contracted with a son or slave, by order ot the father or master, to compel such father or master to stand to the agreement Halll-fax, Civil Law, b. 3, c. 2, no. 3; InsL 4, 7, 1

title: Quod Non Fuit Negatum
body: which was not denied. A phrase found in the old reports, signifying that an argument or prop-osition was not denied or controverted by the court. Latch, 213

title: Quod Nota
body: which note; which mark. A reporter’s note in the old books, directing attention to a point or rule. Dyer, 23

title: Quod Partes Replacitent
body: That the parties do replead. The form of the judgment on award of a repleader. 2 Salk. 579

title: Quod Partitio Fiat
body: That parti-tion be made. The uame of the judgment in a suit for partition, directing that a partition be effected

title: Quod Permittat
body: That he permit In old English law. A writ which lay for the heir of him that was disseised of his common of pasture, against the heir of the disseisor. Cowell

title: Quod Permittat Prosternere
body: That he permit to abate. In old practice. A writ, in the, nature of a w’rlt of right, which lay to abate a nuisance. 3 Bl. Comm. 221. And see Conhocton Stone Road v. Buffalo, etc., R. Co., 51 N. Y. 579, 10 Am. Rep. 646; Powell v. Furniture.Co., 34 W. Va. 804, 12 S. E. 1085, 12 L. R. A. 53; Miller v. True-hart, 4 Leigh (Va.) 577.

title: Quod Prostravit
body: That he do abate. The name of a judgment upon an in-dictment for a nuisance, that the defendant abate such nuisance

title: Quod Recuperet
body: That he recover The ordinary form of judgments for the plaintiff in actions at law. 1 Archb. Pr. K. B. 225; 1 Burrlll, Pr. 246

title: Quod Si Contingat
body: That lf it happen. words by which a condition might formerly be created in a deed. Litt. | 330

title: Quod Vide
body: whlch see. A direction to the reader to look to another part of tbe hook, or to another book, there named, for further information

title: Quoniam Attachiamenta
body: (Since the attachments.) one of the oldest books in the Scotch law. So called from the two first words of the volume. Jacob; whishaw

title: Quorum
body: when a’committee, board of directors, meeting of shareholders, legis) a-tlve or other body of persons cannot nct un-less a certaln number nt least of them are present, that number is called a “quorum.” Sweet. In the absence of any law or rule fixing the quorum, it consists of a majority of those entitled to act. See Ex parte willcocks, 7 Cow. (N. Y.) 409, 17 Am. Dee. 525; State v. wilkesville Tp., 20 ohio St. 293; Heiskell v. Baltimore, 65 Md. 125, 4 Atl. 116, 57 Am. Rep. 308; Snider v. Rlne hart, 18 Colo. 18, 31 Pac. 716

title: Quot
body: In old Scotch law. A twentieth part of the movable estate of a person dying, which was due to the bishop of the dio-cese within which the person resided. Bell

title: Quota
body: A proportional part or share, the proportional part of a demand or liabll-ity, falling upon each of those who are col lectlvely responsible for the whole

title: Quotation
body: 1. The production to a conrt or judge of the exact language of a statute, precedent, or other authority, in support of an argument or proposition ad-vanced

title: Quotient Verdict
body: A money ver dict the amount of which is fixed hy the following process: Each Juror writes down the sum he wishes to award by the verdict; these amounts are all added together, and the total is divided by twelve, (the number of the jurors,) and the quotient stands as the verdict of the jury by their agreement. See Hamilton v. Owego waterworks. 22 App Dlv. 573, 48 N. Y. Supp. 10G; Moses v. Railroad Co., 3 Misc. Rep. 322, 23 N. Y. Supp. 23

title: Quotuplex
body: Of how many kinds; how many fold. A term of frequent occurrence in Sheppard’s Touchstone

title: Quousque
body: Lat. How long; how far; until. In old conveyances it is used as a word of limitation. 10 Coke, 41

title: Quovts Modo
body: Lat in whatever manner
